headline: A really simple guide to the presidential vote

annotations.paragraph: Republican Donald Trump is preparing to select his top team ahead of his return to the White House, after a decisive election victory.
annotations.reason: Provides new information about the election outcome and Trump's actions post-victory.

annotations.paragraph: His defeated opponent, Democrat Kamala Harris, vowed to support a "peaceful transfer of power".
annotations.reason: Offers relevant information about the response of the defeated candidate.

annotations.paragraph: The 2024 election was on Tuesday, 5 November 2024.
annotations.reason: States the date of the election, which is essential context.

annotations.paragraph: Ahead of election day, some tens of millions of people took part in early voting events or sent their ballots by post. Tens of millions more voted on election day itself.
annotations.reason: Provides context on voter turnout and voting methods.

annotations.paragraph: The winner will serve a term of four years in the White House, starting in January 2025.
annotations.reason: Gives relevant information about the term length and start date for the presidency.

annotations.paragraph: On the world stage, the US leader has considerable freedom to represent the country abroad.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides context on the president's role in international affairs.

annotations.paragraph: Within the US, the president works with the two branches of the US Congress to pass legislation.
annotations.reason: This paragraph explains the president's legislative role within the US government.

annotations.paragraph: They can also issue executive orders, which can direct the operations of the federal government, or clarify and extend existing laws.
annotations.reason: This paragraph details the president's power to issue executive orders.

annotations.paragraph: The president also has the power to issue pardons for federal crimes.
annotations.reason: This paragraph describes another specific power of the president.

annotations.paragraph: The period after the election is known as the transition, which gives the new administration time to appoint cabinet ministers and make plans for the new term.
annotations.reason: This paragraph provides relevant information about the post-election transition period.

annotations.paragraph: Trump becomes the president-elect, Vance the vice-president-elect.
annotations.reason: This provides essential information about the election outcome.

annotations.paragraph: At his victory rally, Trump hinted Kennedy - a former Democrat and vaccine sceptic - would be given a key healthcare role.
annotations.reason: This offers new information about potential appointments in the administration.

annotations.paragraph: Technology billionaire Elon Musk is also expected to feature in the new administration. Trump previously said he would ask Mr Musk to tackle government waste.
annotations.reason: This provides relevant details about possible administration roles.

annotations.paragraph: Trump will be sworn in at a ceremony known as the inauguration, held on the steps of the Capitol building in Washington DC on Monday 20 January 2025.
annotations.reason: This gives important information about the inauguration date and location.

annotations.paragraph: At that point, he legally assumes the power and responsibilities of the presidency.
annotations.reason: This explains the significance of the inauguration event.

annotations.paragraph: The Democrats, who use blue as their colour, are the liberal political party. They are known for supporting civil rights, a social safety net and measures to address climate change.
annotations.reason: Provides background on the Democratic party relevant to understanding the election.

annotations.paragraph: In the 2024 election, issues highlighted by their candidate Kamala Harris included tackling the cost-of-living crisis and supporting abortion rights.
annotations.reason: Directly relates to the 2024 election and the Democratic candidate's platform.

annotations.paragraph: The Republicans use the colour red and are the conservative political party. They have stood for lower taxes, shrinking the size of the government and gun rights.
annotations.reason: Provides background on the Republican party relevant to understanding the election.

annotations.paragraph: Issues that their candidate Donald Trump campaigned on included tackling illegal immigration and ending inflation to "make America affordable again".
annotations.reason: Directly relates to the 2024 election and the Republican candidate's platform.

annotations.paragraph: The winner is not the person who gets the most votes overall. Instead, both candidates compete to win contests held across the 50 individual states.
annotations.reason: Explains the electoral process, which is crucial to understanding the presidential vote.

annotations.paragraph: Each state has a certain number of so-called electoral college votes, partly based on population. There are a total of 538 up for grabs and the winner is the candidate that gets 270 or more. A tie is possible, but unlikely.
annotations.reason: Provides essential information about how the electoral college system works.

annotations.paragraph: All but two states have a winner-takes-all rule, so whichever candidate has the highest number of votes is awarded all of its electoral college votes.
annotations.reason: Explains the winner-takes-all rule which is crucial to understanding the voting process.

annotations.paragraph: Most states lean heavily towards one party or the other, so the focus is on about seven states where either of them could win. These are known as the battleground or swing states.
annotations.reason: Identifies key battleground states which are central to the election outcome.

annotations.paragraph: It is possible for a candidate to win the most votes nationally - as the Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton did in 2016 - but still be defeated.
annotations.reason: Highlights a critical aspect of the electoral system where the popular vote does not guarantee victory.

annotations.paragraph: Most of the attention is on who wins the presidency, but voters were also choosing new members of Congress - where laws are passed.
annotations.reason: Provides context about concurrent congressional elections, which is relevant to the overall election process.

annotations.paragraph: Congress consists of the House of Representatives, where all 435 seats were up for election, and the Senate, where 34 seats were being contested.
annotations.reason: Provides essential context about the congressional elections happening alongside the presidential vote.

annotations.paragraph: These two chambers pass laws and can act as a check on White House plans if the controlling party in either chamber disagrees with the president.
annotations.reason: Explains the significance of congressional control in relation to presidential power.

annotations.paragraph: Republicans have retaken control of the US Senate, which votes on key appointments in government.
annotations.reason: Offers a specific update on the outcome of the Senate elections, relevant to the political landscape.

annotations.paragraph: They also lead the contest to control the House of Representatives, which initiates spending plans, but it could take days for the final result to be confirmed.
annotations.reason: Provides current status and implications of the House election results.
